metadata.description: Energy Community bonus credit categories qualifying for 10% ITC adder under IRA Section 48(e). Projects located in qualifying energy communities receive an additional 10 percentage points on their Investment Tax Credit.
sources: IRS Notice 2024-30 (Energy Community Bonus Credit Amounts)
IRS Notice 2023-47 (Initial Guidance on Energy Communities)
DOE / Interagency Working Group on Energy Communities
Treasury Final Rule on Energy Community Bonus (2024)
metadata.itc_bonus: 10% for projects meeting prevailing wage and apprenticeship (PWA) requirements; 2% for projects under 1 MW AC that do not meet PWA

categories.description: Sites with real or perceived environmental contamination, as defined under CERCLA (Superfund) or similar state programs. Building solar on contaminated or previously contaminated land.
categories.qualification: Must be a brownfield site as defined in CERCLA Section 101(39) — real property where expansion, redevelopment, or reuse may be complicated by the presence or potential presence of a hazardous substance, pollutant, or contaminant. Includes EPA Brownfield sites, state-designated brownfield sites, Superfund sites, and certain landfills.
categories.verification: Environmental site assessment (Phase I or Phase II ESA), EPA Brownfield listing, state environmental agency designation, or inclusion in CERCLA/Superfund inventory.
key_characteristics: Site must be directly on or contain the brownfield
Includes former industrial sites, gas stations, landfills, mines
Can overlap with coal closure or fossil fuel employment categories (but bonus only claimed once)

sample_areas.description: New Jersey has 20,000+ known contaminated sites — highest density in US. Many ideal for solar.
Former steel mill sites along Monongahela River
Former industrial sites on South Side and along Chicago River
Former manufacturing sites along Cuyahoga River flats
Extensive brownfield inventory from auto manufacturing decline

categories.description: Census tracts that have had a coal mine close after December 31, 1999, or a coal-fired electric generating unit retire after December 31, 2009, PLUS any census tract that is directly adjoining such a tract.
categories.qualification: Census tract contains (or is directly adjacent to a tract containing) a coal mine that closed after 1999 OR a coal-fired power plant unit that retired after 2009. Adjacency means sharing a border (including corner adjacency). Uses Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) data for coal mines and EIA-860 data for power plants.
categories.verification: DOE/IRS Energy Community mapping tool at energycommunities.gov. Census tract lookup confirms eligibility. No site-specific environmental assessment needed — geographic qualification only.
key_characteristics: Based on census tract geography, not specific site
Adjacent tracts also qualify (significant coverage expansion)
Uses MSHA mine closure data and EIA power plant retirement data
Status updated annually based on new closures/retirements
Many tracts qualify in Appalachia, Midwest, Mountain West

sample_areas.description: Multiple coal mine closures since 2000. Heart of southern WV coal country.
Coal mine closures along Tug Fork river valley
Multiple coal-fired power plant retirements including Hatfield's Ferry (2013)
Homer City Generating Station (closed units since 2012)
Powder River Basin — world's largest coal mining region. Multiple mines closed/reduced operations.
W.H. Sammis power plant retirement. Ohio River valley coal country.
Appalachian coal mine closures. Pike County lost hundreds of mining jobs since 2010.
Alabama coal mine closures. Gorgas Steam Plant retired units.
Multiple coal plant retirements in Terre Haute area.
Hayden Station coal plant scheduled retirement. Northwest Colorado coal transition.

categories.description: Metropolitan Statistical Areas (MSAs) or non-metropolitan statistical areas (non-MSAs) that have significant fossil fuel employment or tax revenue AND have an unemployment rate at or above the national average.
categories.qualification: Two criteria BOTH must be met: (1) The MSA or non-MSA county has 0.17% or more direct fossil fuel employment as a percentage of total employment, OR 25% or more of local tax revenue derived from fossil fuel extraction/processing/transport; AND (2) The area has an unemployment rate at or above the national average unemployment rate for the prior year. Status is re-evaluated annually based on BLS and Census data.
categories.verification: DOE/IRS Energy Community mapping tool at energycommunities.gov. MSA/non-MSA lookup. Updated annually — an area can gain or lose eligibility year to year based on unemployment rate changes.
key_characteristics: Applies to entire MSA or non-MSA county — broad geographic coverage
Both employment/revenue AND unemployment thresholds must be met simultaneously
Eligibility can change annually as unemployment rates fluctuate
Fossil fuel employment includes extraction, processing, transport of oil, gas, and coal
Some areas cycle in and out of eligibility based on unemployment rate

sample_areas.description: Permian Basin oil & gas hub. 15%+ of employment in fossil fuels. Eligibility depends on annual unemployment rate comparison.
Surrounding Permian Basin counties with high fossil fuel employment ratios.
Bakken formation shale oil center. Very high fossil fuel employment percentage.
Coal-dependent counties with above-average unemployment. Many qualify under both coal closure AND fossil fuel employment categories.
Oil & gas sector headquarters and operations. May qualify depending on annual unemployment comparison.
Oil, gas, and coal employment center. Wyoming's energy economy makes many areas eligible.
Oil, gas, and coal operations in Four Corners region. San Juan Generating Station retirement.
Offshore oil & gas support industry hub. High fossil fuel employment ratio.
Marcellus Shale gas extraction center.
Prudhoe Bay oil production. Extremely high fossil fuel employment percentage.
DJ Basin oil and gas operations. Significant fossil fuel employment.

stacking_rules.description: The energy community bonus can be combined with other ITC adders.

stackable_with.requirement: Located in low-income community (10%) or Indian land/qualified low-income residential building/qualified low-income economic benefit project (20%)

maximum_itc_example.notes: A commercial solar project in an energy community using domestic-content equipment with PWA compliance can achieve up to 50% ITC. Low-income adder can push to 60-70% in specific cases.

data_update_schedule.coal_closure: Updated as new closures/retirements are reported. MSHA and EIA databases updated quarterly.
data_update_schedule.fossil_fuel_employment: Re-evaluated annually. BLS unemployment data typically finalized by April for prior year. MSA qualification list published each spring/summer.
data_update_schedule.brownfield: No fixed schedule — site-specific determination based on environmental records.
